message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest blepharitis, and the next best step in management is Lid hygiene and warm compresses. Oral doxycycline is used for severe cases, but it’s not the first line of treatment. Topical cyclosporine is used for dry eye disease, which is not the case here. Topical mupirocin is used for bacterial skin infections, which is not the cause of the symptoms here.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the symptoms, the patient is likely suffering from blepharitis, an inflammation of the eyelid margins. The symptoms improve after a hot shower, indicating that warm compresses and lid hygiene would be beneficial in managing her condition. Oral doxycycline may be considered in more severe cases, but is not necessary for this patient. Topical cyclosporine and topical mupirocin are not indicated for blepharitis.

Topical mupirocin is not always effective in treating blepharitis, and oral doxycycline is often reserved for more severe cases. Topical cyclosporine is used to treat inflammatory conditions of the eye, but not specifically for blepharitis. Lid hygiene and warm compresses are the first-line treatment for blepharitis, and can be followed by topical antibiotics if needed.
